Yes, it is frustrating to think that many people oppose scientific discoveries simply because they challenge established beliefs or traditions. However, it is important to remember that the Scientific Revolution occurred during a time when scientific inquiry was still a relatively new concept, and many people still relied on traditional sources of knowledge and authority.

Additionally, many of these discoveries challenged deeply ingrained beliefs about the nature of the world and the place of humans within it. For example, the heliocentric model challenged the idea that humans were at the center of the universe, while the discovery of microorganisms challenged the idea that living things were fundamentally different from non-living matter. These ideas were disruptive to some people's worldview and threatened their sense of identity and meaning.

Despite the opposition, the Scientific Revolution marked a major turning point in human history and laid the foundation for modern science and technology. It also demonstrated the importance of empirical evidence and rational inquiry in uncovering the mysteries of the world around us.
